. It is described as being the most perfect surviving example of a Tudor village in the
. Much of the village is owned by The National Trust.

The Chiding Stone from which the village derives it's name is a large sandstone rock formation, and tradition asserts that the stone was used as a seat of judgement, mainly to remonstrate overbearing local wives.

value: content=This parish church is a beautiful Grade II* listed sandstone church and is, perhaps, the fourth built on the site. In the churchyard is a mausoleum dating from 1736 built by Henry Streatfeild; leading down into the family vault beneath which has a through flow of air provided by vents in two false altar tombs.   The church was almost destroyed by a lightning fire in 1624.

content=Open to the public and houses Buddhist, Egyptian and Japanese artefact collections.  It dates back to the early 1500s, owned by the Streatfeild family and in the early 1800s was re-built by Henry Streatfeild to resemble a medieval castle.  The castle was sold to Lord Astor in 1938, and then served as a base for military forces during the Second World War.  It then became Long Dene school until 1954 when the school was closed.
